Last Thursday was a long day. The paper was behind
schedule, and we were all exhausted by the time we
finished. Having worked on the paper from approximately
ten a.m. Thursday until slightly after five a.m. Friday, those
who were still left felt lucky to have enough energy to walk
home. Somehow, the driver got the flats, and was on his
way to Westminster.
At around 6:15 a.m. Friday, I received a phone call. It
was our driver. He had forgotten the pictures for that issue,
and was already at the printer's in Westminster, and he
wanted to know if I could drive up to Westminster and
deliver them. I mumbled something about 'call somebody
else,' and tried to go back to sleep. Five minutes later, the
phone rang again, and I wa's told that nobody else
answered, and would I please come up to Westminster? I
said that I was too tired, and to attempt to drive at that
ungodly hour would be tantamount to suicide, so let me go
back to sleep, o.k.?
That was mistake one. The driver should have been told
to drive back, or run gray spaces, of a picture of a tree, or
something. As it was, this was his second week of being
responsible, and he didn't know what to do.
Resorting to the picture file of the Carroll County Times,
he found a wealth of pictures. Unfortunately, half of them
were brides, the rest were Klansmen from a recent rally,
with a few farm shots sprinkled in. Hence the grotesque
assortment which greeted last week's readers..
Just for the record, we were all appalled at the choice of
the Klansman for the cover, although I have been told that
no malice was intended. The News-Letter does not now,
nor has it ever supported the Ku Klux Klan, and I can only
express contempt for them as a political entity. The driver
was severely chastised, and The News-Letter extends its
deepest apologies to any who were offended by the picture.
While we're apologizing, it should be pointed out that
neither Jennifer Bishop (Photo-Production Manager) nor
Izzie Eisner (Photo Production Assistant) had anything to
do with this fiasco, and we also wish to apologize to veteran
photographer David Porter, whose photo credit graced a
blank space. These people have done nothing but good,
painstaking work, and accordingly we are doubly
embarrassed.
Finally, we would like to explain that the reason the eyes
were whited out was that we did not have proper
permission from those portrayed to run the photos, and
thus their eyes were covered as a legal precaution.

At the heart of the Bakke case is the issue of
whether reverse discrimination is a "necessary and
proper" means of facilitating social equality for
black people in the U.S. It is unreasonable that
Allen Bakke be denied admission into the U.C. Med
School because he is white; it is equally
unreasonable that at least sixteen black candidates
be guaranteed admission precisely because they are
black. The unfairness implicit in both instances is
glaringly obvious, but the historical and present
situation of blacks in the U.S. has made such an
action necessary.
The major part of black "immigration" was
accomplished by the early 19th century; that of
white immigrants not until the late 19th century.
Although a higher percentage of black families were
here sooner than their white counterparts, the
assimilation of black people into American culture
has been a much slower, more painstaking process.
There are several reasons for the slowness of this
process. In reference to slavery there was an active,

economic interest in preventing assimilations
Subsequent to slavery, blacks remained at tiv
bottom of the social structure. They were different
they had been treated differently, and the
difference in skin color made it more difficult f6
blacks to maintain themselves as equals in
predominantly white society.
The effects of such discrimination are
unquestionably, in evidence today. Comparison°
1975-1976 figures indicate that nationwide, th
number of poverty level families went down 3.5
for blacks, the figure was up .7%. Analysis of tilt
average annual income follows the same trend. Th'
average annual income for whites in 1976 beirl
$15,537; for Hispanics $10, 259 (up 1.6%); f°
blacks $9,242(down .5%).
It is impossible to hold that social equality exist'
in the U.S. Reverse discrimination is a "necessal?
and proper" step towards achieving such equality,1,
is indeed regrettable that a more effective means t'
such an end does not exist.

J. Kelson Weber, a
vice-president of A.C. Nielsen
Co., spoke Tuesday to an
audience of about one hundred
in Shriver Hall as part of the
continuing Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium, "Television: The
W.orld in Twenty-One Inches
(diagonally)."
Mr. Weber's assigned topic was
"The Ratings Game," but, as he
said, "ratings are a lot more than
a game." To illustrate his point,
Mr. Weber presented a slide show
explaining the Nielsen system of
data collection.
Mr. Weber compared Nielsen's
job to that of a ticket-taker at a
movie theatre. "If one
ticket-taker reports a hundred
tickets were bought to see
'Hamlet' and 10,000 tickets to
see 'Star Wars', it would be quite
clear which movie the owner
would book to get the most
amount of people in his theatre."
Mr. Weber continued by saying
that "John Q. Public" believes
.the Nielsen Company actually
tells' the networks which
programs to schedule, but that's
a falsity, because iMelien only
reports the number of people
watching a certain show at a
given time.
The data reported by A.C.
Nielsen falls into two categories.
The SIA, an automatic recording
device attached to the television
set, transmits the relevant data
(what is being watched and
when) to Nielsen's headquarters
in Florida via telephone lines.
This system allows the company
to estimate the size of the
viewing audience overnight. The

other system, which is more
interested ir who is watching a
particular show, relies on a diary
kept in 2500 homes during
eleven selected weeks. This diary
reveals the demographics of a
specific portions of the audience,
which is the data that most
concerns advertisers.

BY LUDWIG KOECHEL
It used to be that an all-Beethoven program by a
symphony orchestra was not much of an oddity.
Certainly, much of any orchestra's concert repetoire was
comprised almost solely of the established masters:
Beethoven, Brahms, Mozart, Haydn, and so on. Once in a
while, the listener was treated to such rare delicacies as
Sibelius, Mahler or Schoenberg, but on the whole it was a
steady diet of staid and oft-played warhorses.
However, American orchestras are finally, begrudgingly
following their European brethren into the twentieth
century. Perhaps following the lead of Pierre Boulez with
the New York Philharmonic, what was once considered
standard fare is avoided in favor of lesser known, but
equally meritorious compositions of this century.
The Baltimore Symphony seems to be following a
similar tack, but not quite. Rather than approach a.
concert program as a means merely to include music,
SerOu Commisiona seems to hold that a concert should
be constructed in such a way that each piece serves to
illuminate the others by comparison and performance.
One wonders, then, how such a seemingly didactic
sense of programming could accomodate an all-Beethoven
concert, for at first the answer would not seem easy. Yet
if one places Beethoven's career in historical perspective,
and applies an analysis of his stylistic development, it
would seem most enlightening to play certain Beethoven
works against others, so to speak.
Or at least that was the impression received at
Wednesday's performance. Certainly, the choice of the
Symphony No. 2 in D (Op. 36) and the Piano Concerto
No. 3 in c minor (Op. 37) seemed to be anything but.
coincidental. What was curious, though, was that the
concert opened with the Leonora Overture No. 1 (Op.
138), which, although it was a later work than the other.
two, was positioned as if it had been earlier.
On the whole, the Overture was played typically well,
although one begins to wonder if the Orchestra will ever,

get an adequate horn section ,it is not so much the notes
(although in the Symphony No. 2 there was an appalling
octave-voiced unison which somehow wasn't an octave or
in unison), but the incredible ugliness of tone left this
listener considerably annoyed.
Throughout the Overture, as well as the Symphony,
both the strings and the woodwinds were positively
stunning in their sense of ensemble. The richness of the
violins and celli seemed especially reminiscent of the best
in string playing while the woodwinds produced a dark,
rich tone which left the ear with the same sheer
satisfaction good chocolate leaves the palate.
In fact, the only possible argument one could have with
the performance is that , if, as we are assuming,
.Comissiona wanted to obtain a Classical sense with these
pieces, why then did he retain the full orchestra
throughout? Did he wish to emphasize the difference
between Beethoven and the Classicists he developed from,
or was it merely that he felt that the modern ear deserves
the pampering of the overly large orchestra to wnich it
has become accustomed?
It was with the Piano Concerto that the real problems
began. Eugene Istomin, who is a brilliant pianist in his
own right, seemed somehow the wrong choice for this
work.
It wasn't his playing which offended, as at least he
seemed to have the same sense of texture as Comissiona's
Orchestra; but rather his tone. Although the flat,
crystalline texture of his playing, which shimmered and
glowed throughout, would have been fine for a romantic
or impressionist piece, one couldn't help but feel that it
was somehow cold with respect to the Beethoven.
There were, of course, moments when that dry attack
worked quite well, as in the first movement when the
piano enters, and seems almost to be echoing a sense of
construction from the Mozart concerti. But by the second
movement one began to weary of this style, just as one
grows tired of a dry wit throughout a serious moment.

audition tapes. While Mr. Kefauver handles such

tapes, the student assistants perform what he calls
the "grunt" work --duplications and
undergraduate recitals.

starts (microphone placement and equipment
checks), the work afterwards is often
time-consuming and tedious. For example, a
:wo-and-one-half hour concert requires six hours
f editing applause, making leader tape,
:ataloguing and filing the tape.
-" Recording at the Peabody studio is quite
simple, the sound is picked up on microphones
and wired into the studio, where Mr. Kefauver

determines the levels and dynamic balance. Mr.
Kefauver, who has a classical music education and
plays French Horn with the Gettysburg, and
Annapolis Symphonies, claims that a classical
background is essential for this fine tu fling. Only
classical music is recorded at Peabody; the studio
is not designed for rock music.

problem of the Peabody recording studio is
money. Replacing old equipment is often
postponed because of expense; meanwhile,
maintenance problenis affecting the quality of
the recordings have resulted from the studio's
forty-hour-per-week schedule. Vandalism of

to the studio. He commented that a $12 to
$15,000 outlay would be needed to obtain a
"professional (control) board" that would lower
noise, decrease distortion, and offer greater
acoustic flexibility.

Friday. Peabody students can rent the studio for

ensembles only. Many students also buy concert
duplications, which arc available at a much lower
price than the original recordings. According to

Hopkins students have used the Peabody facility.

McLuhan Revisited
In the two weeks since the publication of my article on
Marshall McLuhan, I have become aware of what I
Perceive to be widespread discontent • not only with
„cl-uhan's talk, but with the man himself. While I will be
the first
to agree that his presentation lacked organization
and, was too broad in scope for the symposiumlformat, I
u° not believe
that a judgment of the man's work can be
_de
solely on the basis of his speech that afternoon.
r. McLuhan
is 66. His work spans the fields of
education,
literature, business management, sociology,
ItItal history, and the media, to name but a few.
t`eterences to his books and articles appear in every major
ledia
textbook currently in use. His works are consulted
°Y social
scientists and businessmen alike.
Some of
his ideas are unusual, his premises shaky. But
(1,, is a
Philosopher. He does not claim to have theories; he
ues not prescribe
solutions to problems. He is an

investigator whose function is to probe in search of truth.
It he said what seemed agreeable .to audiences, he would
not be a pioneer. In order to progress iatellectually ,it is
necessary to suggest what seems impossible in the current
context, and to challenge all that the current
establishment represents. That is what separates the
creative thinker from the rest of us.
In an interview with sociologist Robert K. Merton in
1966, McLuhan gave this reply to his questions: "You're
not trying to explore anything with me. You're exploring
my statements. I don't agree with them. I merely use
them as probes."
I will not begin to describe the two days that Dr.
McLuhan spent in Baltimore. Suffice it to say that he
could have been made more comfortable. And that he
could have been better informed as to what kind of
audience to expect. Considering these disadvantages, I

you'd say that Dr. McLuhan cannot be held totally
esponsible for failing to reach the whole audience.
Marshall McLuhan may not conform to traditional
Aandards of what a "scholar" should be. Nevertheless, his
•ontributions to the study of media have revolutionized
the communication industry. His relentless pursuit of
innovative perspectives on culture and technology place
him in the forefront of his field. True, he does not come
across very well to a large audience, but as one who has
read books by and about him, as well as had the pleasure
of spending a few hours with him in informal
conversation, I have no reservations whatsoever in praising
him as an unusually learned, creative, and yes, brilliant
man.

BY LUDWIG KOECHEL
It used to be that an all-Beethoven program by a
symphony orchestra was not much of an oddity.
Certainly, much of any orchestra's concert repetoire was
comprised almost solely of the established masters:
Beethoven, Brahms, Mozart, Haydn, and so on. Once in a
while, the listener was treated to such rare delicacies as
Sibelius, Mahler or Schoenberg, but on the whole it was a
steady diet of staid and oft-played warhorses.
However, American orchestras are finally, begrudgingly
following their European brethren into the twentieth
century. Perhaps following the lead of Pierre Boulez with
the New York Philharmonic, what was once considered
standard fare is avoided in favor of lesser known, but
equally meritorious compositions of this century.
The Baltimore Symphony seems to be following a
similar tack, but not quite. Rather than approach a.
concert program as a means merely to include music,
SerOu Commisiona seems to hold that a concert should
be constructed in such a way that each piece serves to
illuminate the others by comparison and performance.
One wonders, then, how such a seemingly didactic
sense of programming could accomodate an all-Beethoven
concert, for at first the answer would not seem easy. Yet
if one places Beethoven's career in historical perspective,
and applies an analysis of his stylistic development, it
would seem most enlightening to play certain Beethoven
works against others, so to speak.
Or at least that was the impression received at
Wednesday's performance. Certainly, the choice of the
Symphony No. 2 in D (Op. 36) and the Piano Concerto
No. 3 in c minor (Op. 37) seemed to be anything but.
coincidental. What was curious, though, was that the
concert opened with the Leonora Overture No. 1 (Op.
138), which, although it was a later work than the other.
two, was positioned as if it had been earlier.
On the whole, the Overture was played typically well,
although one begins to wonder if the Orchestra will ever,

get an adequate horn section ,it is not so much the notes
(although in the Symphony No. 2 there was an appalling
octave-voiced unison which somehow wasn't an octave or
in unison), but the incredible ugliness of tone left this
listener considerably annoyed.
Throughout the Overture, as well as the Symphony,
both the strings and the woodwinds were positively
stunning in their sense of ensemble. The richness of the
violins and celli seemed especially reminiscent of the best
in string playing while the woodwinds produced a dark,
rich tone which left the ear with the same sheer
satisfaction good chocolate leaves the palate.
In fact, the only possible argument one could have with
the performance is that , if, as we are assuming,
.Comissiona wanted to obtain a Classical sense with these
pieces, why then did he retain the full orchestra
throughout? Did he wish to emphasize the difference
between Beethoven and the Classicists he developed from,
or was it merely that he felt that the modern ear deserves
the pampering of the overly large orchestra to wnich it
has become accustomed?
It was with the Piano Concerto that the real problems
began. Eugene Istomin, who is a brilliant pianist in his
own right, seemed somehow the wrong choice for this
work.
It wasn't his playing which offended, as at least he
seemed to have the same sense of texture as Comissiona's
Orchestra; but rather his tone. Although the flat,
crystalline texture of his playing, which shimmered and
glowed throughout, would have been fine for a romantic
or impressionist piece, one couldn't help but feel that it
was somehow cold with respect to the Beethoven.
There were, of course, moments when that dry attack
worked quite well, as in the first movement when the

McLuhan Revisited
In the two weeks since the publication of my article on
Marshall McLuhan, I have become aware of what I
Perceive to be widespread discontent • not only with
„cl-uhan's talk, but with the man himself. While I will be
the first
to agree that his presentation lacked organization
and, was too broad in scope for the symposiumlformat, I
u° not believe
that a judgment of the man's work can be
_de
solely on the basis of his speech that afternoon.
r. McLuhan
is 66. His work spans the fields of
education,
literature, business management, sociology,
ItItal history, and the media, to name but a few.
t`eterences to his books and articles appear in every major
ledia
textbook currently in use. His works are consulted
°Y social
scientists and businessmen alike.
Some of
his ideas are unusual, his premises shaky. But
(1,, is a
Philosopher. He does not claim to have theories; he
ues not prescribe
solutions to problems. He is an

investigator whose function is to probe in search of truth.
It he said what seemed agreeable .to audiences, he would
not be a pioneer. In order to progress iatellectually ,it is
necessary to suggest what seems impossible in the current
context, and to challenge all that the current
establishment represents. That is what separates the
creative thinker from the rest of us.
In an interview with sociologist Robert K. Merton in
1966, McLuhan gave this reply to his questions: "You're
not trying to explore anything with me. You're exploring
my statements. I don't agree with them. I merely use
them as probes."
I will not begin to describe the two days that Dr.
McLuhan spent in Baltimore. Suffice it to say that he
could have been made more comfortable. And that he
could have been better informed as to what kind of
audience to expect. Considering these disadvantages, I

you'd say that Dr. McLuhan cannot be held totally
esponsible for failing to reach the whole audience.
Marshall McLuhan may not conform to traditional
Aandards of what a "scholar" should be. Nevertheless, his
•ontributions to the study of media have revolutionized
the communication industry. His relentless pursuit of
innovative perspectives on culture and technology place
him in the forefront of his field. True, he does not come
across very well to a large audience, but as one who has
read books by and about him, as well as had the pleasure
of spending a few hours with him in informal
conversation, I have no reservations whatsoever in praising
him as an unusually learned, creative, and yes, brilliant
man.
